questions.text: Most common site of lesion producing hemiballismus?
questions.solution: The most common cause is a partial lesion (infarct or hemorrhage) in the subthalamic nucleus (STN), but in 30-40% of cases the lesion is found in the putamen, thalamus, or parietal cortex.

questions.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen in all except?
questions.solution: Renal tubular acidosis is a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following cognitive functions is usually most impaired early in the course of Alzheimer disease?
questions.solution: The cognitive changes of AD tend to follow a characteristic pattern, beginning with memory impairment and progressing to language and visuospatial deficits, followed by executive dysfunction.

questions.text: In the initial 3 weeks following a TIA what treatment should be given?
questions.solution: Dual antiplatelet and statins for first 3 weeks followed by single antiplatelet and statin life long.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as a rescue therapy during severe "off periods" in Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution: Apomorphine is a D1 and D2 receptor agonist with a rapid onset of action. It can be used subcutaneously as a rescue injection in severe "off periods".

questions.text: Which of the findings does not favor pre-renal azotemia?
questions.solution: In pre-renal azotemia, Fractional excretion of sodium is <1%

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with hypertension, hepatitis C, and chronic liver dysfunction has had two focal seizures with secondary generalization thought to be related to a remote cerebral infarction. Which of the following antiepileptic medications would be best to try first in this patient?
questions.solution: Of the antiepileptic medications listed, all but levetiracetam would be relatively contraindicated in a patient with significant liver disease given that they are hepatically metabolized

questions.text: Most specific antibody in SLE?
questions.solution: Anti Sm antibody is the most specific antibody for SLE

questions.text: Which of the following is an N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist used in management of alzheimer's dementia?
questions.solution: Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used in the treatment of moderate-to-severe Alzheimer disease. Rivastigmine and donepezil are acetylcholinesterase inhibitors used in the treatment of Alzheimer disease. Vigabatrin is a gamma aminobutyric acid (GABA) metabolism inhibitor used to increase GABA activity in the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with complaints of new-onset headache. She is fatigued and has lost about 2.3 kg over the past month. The patient describes daily bitemporal headaches. On further questioning, she describes morning stiffness lasting about 1 hour and aching in the shoulders and hips. She reports transient loss of vision in her right eye for about 30 minutes yesterday before her vision returned. Physical examination findings are unremarkable for her age. Initial laboratory studies show a mild normochromic anemia and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 101 mm/h. Which would be the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: In a patient of this age with a new onset of headache, anemia, and highly elevated ESR, giant cell arteritis would be the number one consideration. Temporal artery biopsy would be appropriate, but with the high degree of suspicion for GCA (because of the loss of vision), prednisone therapy should begin without waiting for the biopsy results. The appropriate dose of prednisone for GCA is 1 mg/kg daily. Lower doses are appropriate for polymyalgia rheumatica. A CT scan of the head would not be helpful for a patient with suspected GCA.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory abnormalities typically can be seen accompanying acute kidney injury?
questions.solution: A variety of electrolyte abnormalities can be seen in AKI including hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. Abnormalities in plasma electrolyte composition can be mild or life-threatening. The dysfunctional kidney has limited ability to regulate electrolyte balance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sudden, brief, jerk like arrhythmic muscle twitch?
The drug Aducanumab was FDA approved by FDA for?
questions.solution: Aducanumab is a amyloid beta-directed antibody indicated to treat Alzheimer's disease. It selectively targets aggregated forms of Aβ, including soluble oligomers and insoluble fibrils.

questions.text: Hepatitis B infection is associated with?
questions.solution: The presence of a polyarteritis nodosa-like vasculitis in patients with hepatitis B together with the isolation of circulating immune complexes composed of hepatitis B antigen and immunoglobulin and the demonstration by immunofluorescence of hepatitis B antigen, IgM, and complement in the blood vessel walls strongly suggest the role of immunologic phenomena in the pathogenesis of this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following headaches is indomethacin responsive?
questions.solution: Both paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua are indomethacin responsive headaches.

questions.text: The initial step in the development of high turnover Renal osteodystrophy?
questions.solution: Hyperphosphatemia triggers the subsequent sequence of events that leads to high bone turnover CKD.

questions.text: Putaminal rim sign is a feature of?
questions.solution: In MSA, MRI can show pathologic iron accumulation in the striatum on T2-weighted scans, high signal change in the region of the external surface of the putamen (putaminal rim) in MSA-p, or cerebellar and brainstem atrophy (the pontine "hot cross bun" sign in MSA-c).

questions.text: Most common extra-articular manifestation in Ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.solution: Most common extra-articular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis is acute anterior uveitis, which occurs in 40% of patients and can antedate spondylitis.

questions.text: Prominent cranial autonomic features are a feature of?
questions.solution: TACs must be differentiated from short-lasting headaches that do not have prominent cranial autonomic syndromes, notably trigeminal neuralgia (TN), primary stabbing headache, and hypnic headache.

questions.text: Tocilizumab is FDA approved in the treatment of?
questions.solution: Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) was FDA approved for this indication. It is used adjunctively to. The side effect profile of tocilizumab includes leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, transaminnase elevation, and hyperlipidemia.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to estimate GFR?
questions.solution: All these formulas can be used to estimate the GFR

choices.text: IV thrombolysis followed by mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: The definitive treatment for a patient with acute left hemiplegia with CT angiogram showing right intracranial ICA and proximal MCA thrombotic occlusion presenting at 5 hours of onset of stroke is?
questions.solution: Since the patient has presented with acute stroke due to large vessel occlusion and within the window period of mechanical thrombectomy, he/she is a candidate for mechanical thrombectomy for revascularization.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause neuropathic joint disease?
Which class lupus nephritis is highly prone to develop thrombosis?
questions.solution: Patients with class V lupus nephritis are highly prone to develop thrombotic complications

questions.text: Alien limb phenomenon is a feature of?
questions.solution: CBS is the least common of the three atypical parkinsonisms and usually presents with asymmetric dystonic contractions and clumsiness of one hand coupled with cortical sensory disturbances manifest as apraxia, agnosia, focal limb myoclonus, or alien limb phenomenon (where the limb assumes a position in space without the patient being aware of the position or recognizing that the limb belongs to him/her)

choices.text: Agonist at 5HT1B and antagonist at 5HT1D receptor
Antagonist at 5HT1B and agonist at 5HT1D receptor

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Sumatriptan?
questions.solution: Sumatriptan is an agonist of 5HT1B and 5HT1D receptor

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Safinamide?
questions.solution: Safinamide is a reversible MAO-B inhibitor that has recently been approved as an adjunct to levodopa in advanced PD patients with motor fluctuations. The drug also acts to block activated sodium channels and inhibit glutamate release, and is currently being studied as a possible anti-dyskinetic agent.

questions.text: Mixed connective tissue disease is characterised by autoantibodies to:
questions.solution: Mixed connective tissue is characterised by anti-U1 RNP antibodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for evaluation of cough, which has been persistent over the past 6 months. He is a lifelong non-smoker, and his past medical history is notable only for hypertension, managed with amlodipine and lisinopril. He reports no fever, rash, or joint symptoms. Radiography of the chest shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and upper lobe-predominant nodular pulmonary infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Sarcoidosis is the most likely consideration among the answer choices. Sarcoidosis is compatible with the history of cough in a lifelong nonsmoker in his fourth decade, and the radiographic findings of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and upper lobe-predominant infiltrates would be typical for stage II pulmonary sarcoidosis. IPF would be unlikely in someone so young (it usually affects persons older than 50 years), and the radiographic abnormalities of IPF typically predominate in the lower lobes. Neither amlodipine nor lisinopril is associated with drug-induced ILD, and a patient with lisinopril-associated cough should not have abnormalities on chest imaging.

questions.text: Which test is the most specific for diagnosing limited cutaneous scleroderma?
questions.solution: Anti-centromere antibodies are found in 60% of patients with limited cutaneous scleroderma and the specificity is 98%. Anti-La antibodies are linked to primary Sjogren's syndrome. Anti-Sm antibodies are found in SLE and are directed against RNA-binding proteins. If present, then the patient is at higher risk of glomerulonephritis as part of the disease course.

questions.text: BP above ____ is a contraindication for iv thrombolysis?

A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for recurrent episodes of severe, repetitive stabbing pain in the right forehead and temple that is associated with ipsilateral conjunctival injection, tearing, and photophobia. The attacks last between 1 and 2 minutes and occur at least 100 times daily. Which of the following preventive treatments is most likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution: The clinical picture is consistent with short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT). Lamotrigine is the medication most likely to be effective in this condition.

questions.text: Not a feature of multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring), and neuronal loss

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is strongly associated with each of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution: All the other answers are well-recognized, long-term associations with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: In Trigeminal neuralgia, the blood vessel most often implicated in the compression of trigeminal nerve root?
questions.solution:
Pathophysiology of trigeminal neuralgia

Compression of the trigeminal nerve root by a blood vessel, most often the superior cerebellar artery or on occasion a tortuous vein, is the source of trigeminal neuralgia in most patients.

questions.text: Most common clinical type of multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution: Remiting Relapsing MS (RMS) accounts for 90% of MS cases and is characterized by discrete attacks of neurological dysfunction that generally evolve over days to weeks (rarely over hours).

questions.text: Which of the following is grouped under medium vessel vasculitis?
questions.solution: Kawasaki disease and Polyarteritis nodosa are medium vessel vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical presenting sign or symptom of cerebral venous thrombosis?
questions.solution: Most patients with cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) present with headache, and headache affects approximately 90% of patients with CVT; isolated headaches are not common, however, and may constitute a clinical challenge.

questions.text: Most common chronic dermatitis in Lupus?
questions.solution: Lupus dermatitis can be classified as acute, subacute, or chronic, and there are many different types of lesions encompassed within these groups. Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is the most common chronic dermatitis in lupus; lesions are roughly circular with slightly raised, scaly hyperpigmented erythematous rims and depigmented, atrophic centers in which all dermal appendages are permanently destroyed.

questions.text: Target blood pressure in management of acute intracerebral hemorrhage is systolic BP less than?
questions.solution: Systolic BP target should be less than 140 mmHg.

questions.text: Most effective symptomatic treatment for Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution: Levodopa remains the most effective symptomatic treatment for PD and the gold standard against which new therapies are com-pared. No current medical or surgical treatment provides antiparkinsonian benefits superior to what can be achieved with levodopa. Levodopa benefits the classic motor features of PD, prolongs independence and employability, improves quality of life, and increases life span. Almost all PD patients experience improvement, and failure to respond to an adequate trial of levodopa should cause the diagnosis to be questioned.

questions.text: Martel's sign is seen in?
questions.solution: Martel's sign refers to erosions with overhanging edges seen in gout.

questions.text: Hakim's triad is related to?
questions.solution: Hakim's triad of NPH is dementia, gait disturbance and urinary incontinence.

questions.text: The seronegative spondyloarthropathies are associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: Enthesitis, a common feature of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies, refers to inflammation at the tendon, ligament, or joint capsule insertion. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and enteropathic arthritis. All of these disorders are associated with HLA-B27 and absence of autoantibodies in serum. The seronegative spondyloarthropathies have male predominance, often occur before the age of 40, and cause inflammatory arthritis of the spine and sacroiliac joints.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most sensitive investigation for generalized myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution: Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) is a selective EMG recording technique that allows identification of action potentials from individual muscle fiber.

questions.text: Oliguria is defined as urine output less than:
questions.solution:
Oliguria is urine output less than 400 ml/24 hour

Anuria is urine output less than 100 ml/24 hour

choices.text: Age greater than or equal to 60 years
Blood pressure greater than or equal to 140/90 mm Hg

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical factors is weighted most heavily
when calculating the ABCD2 scale?
questions.solution: The ABCD2 scale is widely employed to predict stroke risk after TIA.

questions.text: Not a risk factor for development of multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution: Well-established risk factors for MS include a genetic predisposition, vitamin D deficiency, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) exposure after early childhood, and cigarette smoking.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is relatively contraindicated in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution: Ciprofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones are one group of medications that are likely to adversely affect neuromuscular transmission. Other groups of antibiotics that may exacerbate myasthenia gravis include the aminoglycosides and macrolides.

questions.text: This 68 year old male presented with progressive dementia over 6 months and myoclonic jerks of 1 month duration. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Diffusion-weighted images demonstrate hyperintense signal that characteristically involves the cortical ribbon of the frontal and parietal lobes, more so on the left side, and the insula. Hyperintense signal change is also seen in the thalamus bilaterally.
